information:
The 2025 Derbyshire County Council election is scheduled for May 1, 2025. This election will use new divisional boundaries, increasing the total number of seats from 61 to 64. Elections for the council operate under a First-Past-The-Post system. According to an assessment, the Conservative Party holds 57 of the 64 seats under the new boundaries. Reform UK currently holds zero seats on the council.

As a newer political party, Reform UK does not have the established local infrastructure and grassroots organization of the main parties active in Derbyshire. The party has encountered issues with candidate vetting, including a controversy involving their candidate for Bakewell, Max Bethell, who reportedly made racial slurs on social media. Historically, predecessor parties like UKIP and the Brexit Party did not succeed in translating national support into control of county councils.

National polling data shows support for Reform UK at approximately 23-25%. A March MRP poll by The Telegraph provided data for the region. The party has confirmed it is running a full slate of candidates across Derbyshire. Political scientist Professor John Curtice has noted that Reform UK's voter support may be more geographically concentrated than widely distributed.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 10–12 days (election May 1, results likely by May 2, 2025)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — one of the established parties (most plausibly Labour, possibly Conservatives) ends up with the most seats; Reform UK is not the largest group.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Reform runs a full slate and polls in the low-to-mid 20s across Derbyshire, but the vote is thinly spread. Labour capitalizes on national swing and urban/industrial areas; Conservatives retain pockets in rural divisions. Under FPTP, Reform finishes second/third in many divisions and wins only a handful at best, leaving Labour or Conservatives as the largest party.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A sharp late swing concentrates Reform’s vote in dozens of divisions (particularly ex‑‘Red Wall’/Brexit‑leaning areas), Conservatives collapse to third, and Labour’s vote is efficient but insufficiently broad. Reform edges out both parties across enough divisions to have the most seats without necessarily winning a majority.
forecast.rationale:
Baseline and structure: Derbyshire County Council elections are FPTP across 64 seats on new boundaries. Reform UK currently has zero councillors and limited local infrastructure. A modelling assessment cited by my assistant suggests the Conservatives would hold 57/64 on notional results under the new map, underscoring how far Reform is from contention absent a major realignment.

Translation problem under FPTP: Even with national polling around 23–25%, new or smaller parties typically struggle to convert vote share into seats without highly efficient geographic concentration. UKIP/Brexit Party historically never controlled a county council and rarely became the largest group anywhere, even at their polling peaks. Reform’s full slate helps coverage but doesn’t solve the conversion hurdle.

Local context and momentum: The Conservatives are likely to lose many seats given national headwinds and local issues, and Labour has strong prospects across Derbyshire’s towns and former industrial areas. Reform has candidate‑quality/discipline issues (e.g., Bakewell controversy) and lacks incumbency advantages. While some Reform support may be regionally concentrated, it would still require dozens of pluralities to top the seat table—an extremely high bar from a standing start.

Why not higher: The combination of (1) starting with zero seats and no incumbency, (2) FPTP seat mechanics, (3) entrenched Labour and Conservative local machines, and (4) historical base rates for insurgent right parties at county level makes Reform becoming the largest group extraordinarily unlikely in the near term.

Why not lower: National polling in the mid‑20s is unusually high for a party with limited local presence. If that support is sharply concentrated in specific parts of Derbyshire (e.g., some ex‑Red Wall divisions) and if Conservative vote collapses while Labour’s is inefficiently distributed, Reform could win more divisions than expected. A volatile environment and a full slate introduce tail risk.

What would move me up: Credible county‑level polling showing Reform leading in many divisions; high‑quality ward/division canvass data indicating Reform is first in a significant share of seats; evidence of multiple last‑minute Conservative defections/endorsements to Reform; strong local by‑election wins in comparable divisions.

What would move me down: Reports of incomplete slates or candidate withdrawals; further vetting scandals; indications Reform is polling in the teens locally; Labour consolidating anti‑Tory vote across key divisions.

Net: The status quo and base rates dominate; a Yes outcome requires an unusually concentrated and large late surge for Reform across dozens of divisions, which is possible but very unlikely.
